boardgame.name: Galactic Keep
Galactic Keep: Dice Battles
boardgame.description:
Galactic Keep: Dice Battles takes core elements of classic dice and paper role playing games and translates them into an iPhone and iPad experience. Set in a dark, sci-fi universe with a strange cast of characters, this uniquely crafted and hand-drawn game is like no other iPhone title out there. Grab loot, battle monsters, mod and level up various characters, unlock new classes and species, and solve item-based puzzles in this modern sim of a classic-feeling tabletop RPG.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Monopoly: Migros
boardgame.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Migros, a company in Switzerland

boardgame.name: Kalory
boardgame.description:
"Kalory: A game for all fun loving, weight conscious people!"

Kalory is a roll-and-move, weight-loss-themed Monopoly derivative which instructs players on methods of losing weight.

After rolling dice, players move their playing pieces around the board, gaining or losing Kalory chips (which represent weight). They also perform actions on cards that they draw, depending on which space they land on. The first player to lose all of their Kalory chips is the winner.

Players may select different game lengths: a lightweight game, a middleweight game, or a heavyweight game. The game length corresponds to an increasing number of starting Kalory chips.

boardgame.name: Hannah Montana Music Game
boardgame.description:
Card game for diehard Hannah Montana fans because you will need to know her songs very well.

Shuffle the deck and place one card face-up next to it. This is the start of the discard pile. Shuffle the Points cards (they vary from 1 to 10 points).

The main cards have a symbol on them. That is important. The symbols are;

Music note: name the title of a Hannah Montana song which includes the word on the card.
Flower: sing 2 lines from the chorus of a Hannah Montana song, which includes the words on the card.
Butterfly: say 3 things about the character on the card.
Star: this is the secret Joker card! Draw a point card without having to carry out an assignment. All other players are required to draw an action card!

The Play. If the player has an action card, of which the colour or symbol corresponds with the top card of the discard pile, he/she can discard it.
If the symbol is identical, then he/she can execute the assignment (see above) on the card he/she is discarding. The other players will judge whether the assignment is successful. If the assignment is successful, then the player can draw 1 points card. If both the symbol and the colour are the same, then the player can draw two points cards! If the assignment was unsuccessful, then the player does not get to draw a points card.
If the symbol is different, but the colour is the same, then he/she does not get to carry out an assignment.
If the player does not have a suitable action card (other symbol and other colour), then he/she has to draw another action card.

The player who has collected the most points when the Points cards have run out is the winner, the Secret Star of the Music Game!

boardgame.name: Moon Base
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

To the untrained eye the moon's surface might look featureless and dreadfully monotonous. And it is true, that this crater seems to be only one among many. Only once an observer gets close to the crater's edge will the base inside the crater become obvious. The base is not much to look at, still two habitat modules have been set up close to the crater wall promising a safe haven. In addition a ramp has been erected connecting the floor of the crater with the higher surrounding ground. While this ramp is wide enough for various vehicles it is not particular sturdy. Even given the moon's low gravity it would be reckless to traverse it with heavy vehicles.

boardgame.name: Tennis Court
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

Almost next to a street lies this small amateur tennis court for the neighborhood. The simple sand court is surrounded by a mesh fence, to stop one or another errant tennis ball, and a low mowed lawn. Inside the fenced in enclosure two simple wooden benches and trashcan sit along one of the courts long sides. Outside the mesh fence a concrete wall on a small paved field allows players without a partner to practice their swings.

boardgame.name: Moon Landing
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

To the untrained eye the moon's surface might look featureless and dreadfully monotonous. Along this small cliff face, possibly the remnant of an old crater, lies one place of importance though. In the bright light and heat of the lunar day a lander has touched down at this spot, marking it with a small flag for all posterity as one of the few spots where man has set foot on their home planet’s natural satellite. In this barren, airless desert the small lunar lander is the only source of hospitality, what little it can provide, far and wide.

boardgame.name: Mad Libs Criss Cross
boardgame.description: Before the game begins each player customizes several of the cards with names of family members, friends, pets etc. in Mad Libs Criss Cross Game. Then each player picks nine cards from the card tray and puts them onto their card holder (3 Nouns, 3 Verbs and 3 Misc.). The first player lays down a sentence made of cards and counts up the total score which is printed on the individual cards. The next player lays down a sentence crossing over or adding to the previous sentence and adds up the score. When all of the cards are used or no one else can make a sentence the game is over. Object of the Game: The player with the most points wins.

boardgame.name: Command Ops: Highway to the Reich
boardgame.description:
As the first official expansion pack for the award winning Command Ops series, Command Ops: Highway to the Reich from acclaimed developer Panther Games brings us to the setting of one of the most epic and controversial battles of World War II: Operation Market-Garden. The Highway to the Reich expansion pack is a set of 13 scenarios covering all of the major actions that took place during the Market Garden Campaign in Holland during September 1944.

The scenarios cover every major engagement along Hell’s Highway, from the surprise capture of Joe’s Bridge by the Irish Guards a week before the offensive to the final battles on “The Island” south of Arnhem. The dramatic parachute and glider landings of the US 82nd and 101st Airborne, The British 1st Airborne and the Polish Brigade are all represented on some of the largest maps ever created for the series and the largest “campaign” scenario in this system to date. More than just a conversion of the old scenarios to play on the new system, the Expansion Pack represents a major update of Panther Games ground breaking classic game Highway to the Reich, incorporating numerous corrections to Maps, Orders of Battle, Unit Compositions, Reinforcement Schedules, and overall game play.

Command Ops: Highway to the Reich is an expansion for Command Ops: Battles from the Bulge and requires the base game to play.

Source: The Publisher Website.

boardgame.name: Fairy Mischief
boardgame.description:
Designed by Jay and Susie Hernishin for their daughter, Fairy Mischief is a light game designed to help younger gamers transition into more advanced gaming with the goal of making more girl analog gamers!

Players take on the roles of fairies competing in displays of magic. The fairies will duel one another over colorful gem pieces that are randomly drawn from a satchel (watch out for the powerful black stones that grant special abilities). When one fairy has won a gem of each of the five colors, they win!

The basic game uses the classic game of War (players win duels by flipping over the top three cards of their deck and comparing who has the highest cards in a best-of-three fashion) combined with other elements to introduce the players to "gamery" skills (collection, special powers, and randomness).

There are also more advanced ways to play, so the game can grow with or adapt to kids. New concepts include (push-your-luck, hand ranks, informed guessing, discard pile awareness, etc.)

boardgame.name: Textra
boardgame.description:
Textra is word game, that consist of a plastic container, 206 letter tiles and 4 letter trays - clearly inspired by Scrabble, but the main gimmick here is the plastic container with clever mechanism to separate vowels and consonants. In the container you have trail where you put your letter tiles to make words. And when the trail is full (something like 15 tiles), the first used letters drop in to two departments one for vowels and other for consonants.

When you start the game, the first player puts one vowel and one consonant in any order in to the trail and then every player gets six letter tiles to make words. You can choose the distribution of vowels and consonants at the start of the game and always when you refill your tile tray. At the players turn you try to make a word using as many already laid letters in a trail as the first letters of your new word. Rest of your word consists of letters you have in your tray. You just put the letters from your tray to the trail to make a new word. Then you multiply newly added letters with letters you used from the previous ones and that makes your points. You fill your hand and then it is the next players turn.

Example: "AUTO" becomes "autoMATIC" (4*5=20 pts.), then "ticK" (3*1), then "tickLE" (4*2) etc.

In a four player game you play to the end of the round, when someone gets total of 60 points. Winner is the player who got the most points. In three player game you play until 80 points and with two players until 100 points. When playing alone you just decide number of rounds and try to make as many points as as you can.

You can play this game as long as you like, because the used letters are dropping back to containers departments, which is the same place where you take the new letter tiles. There is 100 vowel tiles and 100 consonant tiles and six wild tiles in the game. There's quite a few letters missing, that are used in Finnish language. Letter distribution of the game is: vowels: (40*A, 10*E, 20*I 15*O, 15*U) and consonants: (5*H, 5*J, 15*K, 15*L, 5*M, 10*N, 5*P, 5*R, 10*S, 20*T, 5*V). You can play the game in any language, where you can make enough words with these letters. Because of "the clever" mechanism, the vowel tiles are bit smaller than the consonant tiles.

boardgame.name: Gary Grigsby's War in the East: Don to the Danube
boardgame.description:
The critically and fan acclaimed Eastern Front mega-game Gary Grigsby’s War in the East just got bigger and better with Gary Grigsby’s War in the East: Don to the Danube! This expansion to the award-winning War in the East comes with a wide array of later war scenarios ranging from short but intense 6 turn bouts like the Battle for Kharkov (1942) to immense 37-turn engagements taking place across multiple nations like Drama on the Danube (Summer 1944 – Spring 1945). Don to the Danube and the War in the East system gives players unprecedented control over pivotal operations in the Second World War like Operation Uranus, the encirclement of the 6th German Army at Stalingrad, the Cherkassy Pocket and much more. Don to the Danube also takes full advantage of the hefty number of new features and rule changes that come with the massive 1.06.00 update and incorporates a full new Editor manual as well.

Source: The Publisher Website.

boardgame.name: Monopoly: Equipe de France
boardgame.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the winning French soccer team 2000

boardgame.name: Demon Heart Falling
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

NOTES FROM THE TIME MACHINE

I wrote "Demon Bean Falling" in the winter of 1994/1995, when I was a senior at the University of Notre Dame. I'd been running a regular RIFTS campaign for my friends since 1990, and had become obsessed with two things: becoming a writer, and working for Palladium Books. The material in this book (along with the material in its companion, "The Banwok Hunters") reflect a lot of the original material I wrote and used in my ongoing RIFTS campaign during that time.

I submitted both the manuscript for this book and "The Banwok Hunters" to Palladium Books in the spring of 1995. For a while, it looked like Palladium might publish them. Ultimately, they didn't. I learned a lot from that experience, though, and ultimately it helped me to get published, and to become a better writer.

Both "Demon Heart Falling" and "The Banwok Hunters" were put in storage, and were forgotten. I moved on to other games, and other things.

Fast-forward just about fifteen years later, to the fall of 2009.

While looking for some other old games in the attic, I found one of the original copies of "Demon Heart Falling" - probably the only copy still in existence. I'd printed some copies of it for my friends way back in the day, complete with a cover and comb binding. I'd assumed that all copies - including my own - were long-lost to the ravages of time. Wrong. Here was the last copy, staring me in the face.

So I re-read it. And liked it.

It's not the greatest book in the world, I'II be honest. For that matter, it's probably not good. It's decent. It's an excellent reflection of the author I was back then - raw, hungry, passionate, and practically exploding with ideas. It lacks a lot of the polish and refinement needed from a more experienced writer, which could've made it into something far better than what it was. But it's not terrible. It's just a glimpse at the author I was, and the author I would become.

So I present it to you, for your enjoyment. If you can use any of this stuff in your own RIFTS game, awesome. Let me know about it. If not ... well, I hope you enjoy what you read, and it at least makes you smile.

Warts, flaws and all, I'm proud of this one. It told me that I could be a writer.

boardgame.name: The Banwok Hunters
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

" The Banwok Hunters" is a sourcebook intended for the RIFTS roleplaying game.

It's also a snapshot of one of the happiest parts of my life.

I ran a regular RIFTS campaign between 1990 and 1996. For my friends in my regular gaming group - and for myself - that was an amazing time. The games back then were filled with a lot of excitement, a lot of fun, a lot of inspired insanity, and a hell of a lot of laughter.

I spent a lot of time writing adventures and designing new rules and source material for that campaign. At some point, I thought it might be a good idea to formally write up my notes in the form of a book. Little did I know that nearly fifteen years later, this would be the very first step I would take towards becoming a professionally published freelancer in the gaming industry.

"The Banwok Hunters" essentially represents a "best of" look at that campaign, and at my own first attempts at writing something for a gaming company.

Enjoy!

I know my old gaming group did.

boardgame.name: Bolt Action: Assault on Normandy
boardgame.description:
Bolt Action: Assault on Normandy brings to you everything you need to pit your tactics and wits against your opponent as you recreate the great battles of World War II on the tabletop! In addition to the glorious Bolt Action rulebook and eight Orders Dice, you will find forty hard plastic, multi-pose 28mm miniatures as well as terrain for them to fight over. This is a great starting point as you seek to defeat your foes and bring an end to the greatest conflict in history.

This introductory boxed set includes miniatures from two factions – German and Americans – allowing two players to learn the basic rules of the game. Using miniature soldiers, tanks and terrain, you can fight battles in the shattered towns of occupied France, either liberating or holding the position according your faction. By moving miniatures that represent troops and vehicles (like Sherman tanks or half trucks) along a scenery-filled tabletop and using dice to resolve shooting or attacking actions as well as leadership tests, you attempt to finish the enemy army or achieve certain objectives.

boardgame.name: Convert
boardgame.description:
Convert is a two player abstract strategy board game. Two opposing players each have a set of 10 differently shaped wooden blocks that are played on a 4x4 board with alternating black and white squares.

By manipulating pieces to fit on the board, as well as with each other, players attempt to score rows of four while claiming spaces on the board by converting them to their color.

When a player's piece completes a row of four squares, that player scores one point. When all pieces are played, or when neither player can play a piece, players add the points they scored during game-play to the amount of squares they have claimed on the board.

The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

New Second Edition rule set also applies to First (Kickstarter) Edition copies of Convert. New variant play modes, puzzles, and solo mode available. File available in the files section.

Microbadge

Convert fan

boardgame.name: Aastaring Aias
boardgame.description:
Educational board game for kindergartens about vegetables.

There is track on topside of the board and various vegetables growing on the game board under the track.
Player rolls the dice in his turn and moves accordingly on the track. If child lands on square where the name of vegetable is written he/she must recognize this vegetable from the board. Then he/she rolls again and the dice show one of the six categories player must answer the question about this vegetable.
If the answer is incorrect the player moves backward 3 squares.

Player who finishes first is the winner.

boardgame.name: Age of Essence Rule Book
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

Welcome to The Seven Kingdoms, you stand on a continent torn apart by a war that befell us all almost 780 years before now. Before then there was truce between all the races and with the land itself, no one is sure what it was that set the Elves to war but it consumed everything from west to east. For twenty years there was conflict, blood and debris filled the land until one day it all fell silent, no one today knows what truly happened but there were celebrations across all the kingdoms. The aftermath of the war left the seas inaccessible to anyone, raging torrents of storms and seas prevent any ship from sailing to or from the land, the continent shuddered and shifted creating unexplained volcanoes, nothing was spared in the elements mournful wake. A new reform was made so that no war so destructive should ever be brought forth again. To uphold this reform Guilds were created, these guilds are there to keep the balance and to this day still hold great influence across the continent. Many have found honor and glory where others have found wealth and great knowledge. The world turns and now, seven hundred and seventy eight years later things begin to stir in the great forests, dark hearts leak out of the pores of shadows and even magic turns and rebels against itself. These are troubled times and your tale has yet to be told. Will you seek fame and fortune like those before you? Or will your exploits bring about your untimely demise. Whatever the outcome remember that time is of the essence.

boardgame.name: Chains to Champions
boardgame.description:
Chains to Champions is a gladiator themed board game that consists of three phases. In phase one you purchase a gladiator at an auction, in phase two you equip your gladiator with weapons, helmets, armor, and training, and then in phase three all players fight to the death in the Arena. The last man standing wins!

From the back of the box: "Hurry, hurry! The auction is about to begin! There are many gladiators from which to choose. If you choose wisely, you could end up with riches beyond your wildest dreams. If you choose poorly, your gladiator may end up splattered on the sand of the arena. However, the strength behind the swing of his sword isn’t the only thing it takes to make your gladiator a champion. You’ll have access to the finest training and weapons that Rome has to offer before your gladiator is tossed into the arena for a merciless fight to arena in chains, but only one will emerge a champion.

Chains to Champions combines mathematical probability with human ingenuity to create a strategy game that is unique each time you play."

boardgame.name: Breakout 2000
boardgame.description:
Breakout 2000 is a 3-D version of the arcade classic designed for one or two players. There are a total of ten different phases to survive, each consisting of five playfields.

The game featured good and bad power-ups somewhat similar to Arkanoid. There were unbreakable bricks, multi-hit bricks and stacked bricks. Ball movement was limited to the lower level of stacked bricks so breaking a lower brick would allow the stacked bricks to fall into the now vacated location.

The game also featured a two player mode that allowed two people (or a person and the computer) to compete head to head. In this mode a player's ball could loop around to the other player's playfield and break the opponent's bricks. A 2X bonus was awarded for breaking your opponent's bricks.

Source: Wikipedia, "Breakout 2000", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Back of Box

The Breakout Barrage!

SMASH! POW! CRUNCH! Is your hand/eye coordination up to demolishing field after field of bricks? Breakout 2000 brings back the nostalgia of early gaming days but adds 90's challenges, such as a three-dimensional field and bricks that resist breaking, as well as many powerups and hazards. You can also test your skill against a buddy. Break through your own wall and start working on his. You'll gain bonus points, and he'll go nuts! Who ever said life was fair never played Breakout 2000.

boardgame.name: Dwellers in Dream
boardgame.description:
publisher blurb

Long have the fey captured mankind’s imaginations. Dwellers in Dream is a fey-themed player sourcebook containing five all-new races for the Pathfinder RPG. This new sourcebook explores five original fey-themed races for your d20 and Pathfinder games. These are not your standard fantasy fey either, these are creations from the darkest recesses of the twisted minds over at Total Party Kill Games.

The first of the five new player races is the Briarborn, a plant-like race born of nature’s response to harm and injury. They grow quickly and are a measured response to the likes of orcs and men who would seek to harm the world itself. Then there are the Crimbil, goblin-blooded fey and snatchers of children. Next, we explore the True Changelings, mercurial shape-shifting fey. There is also the Glimmerkin, a race of elves who used magic to enter a chrysalis state for an age and emerged something altogether different. Lastly is the Sylfaen, a brutal warden of nature and fey lands, the leaders of the Wyld Hunts.

Each race is fully developed with a total of 80 pages of content! There are tons of new fey-themed feats, abilities, traits, archetypes, spells, magical items and even a new plane of existence. All of the content is hyperlinked to the d20pfsrd.com website for your convenience of use and extensively bookmarked.

boardgame.name: Defender 2000
boardgame.description:
Defender 2000 is a game developed for the Atari Jaguar in 1995 by Jeff Minter. The game contains 3 modes of gameplay (Defender Classic, Defender Plus, and Defender 2000), as well 2 hidden mini-games: Flossie's Revenge & Plasma Pong.

Source: Wikipedia, "Defender 2000", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Back of Box

Will They Never Learn?

You whomped the aliens from the Alpha Proximian Empire in classic Defender and sent them home to cry. Now they want the planets that Earth is mining for desperately needed, life-sustaining minerals. Your job is to protect the space miners as they perform their vital work. The aliens will try to capture them and use their life-energy to turn their ships into hyper-fast mutants. Rescue the captives and destroy the aliens or Earth is history!

boardgame.name: Maximum Throwdown
boardgame.description:
Maximum Throwdown pits up to six players against one another in a battle royale of card-throwing action.

Each player has an individual deck of cards, and they take turns throwing the cards onto a shared playing area to try to cover up the icons of opponents' cards while keeping their own icons visible. On each turn, you draw one card from your deck and throw one card – but if you have the right icons in play, you'll draw more cards, throw more cards, steal cards from opponents and dump them in the gutter, break free of the shared playing space in order to keep from being covered, and – perhaps most important of all – score points each turn you have enough visible icons in play. After all the cards have been tossed, whoever has the most points wins!

boardgame.name: Galipotes
boardgame.description:
There's commotion in the village! The legendary Galipote, who, years ago, terrorized walkers in the west of France, has been seen at night, hidden behind the old oak tree : giant eyes, large jaws and big claws, of either green, yellow or red color.

At the beginning of each round, each player start with a hand of 7 Galipote cards.

During his turn, a player can places one of his card as Testimonial, on one of the 6 available sides, matching half-symbols and colors. If there is a Legend card available, he can places up to 2 cards according to the Legend. If he places a card with fur on the side, other players vote for the new Legend card. If he complete the Figure of Galipotes in one side (a symbol), he can score the cards for him.

The first player to get rid of all his cards, there is one turn until the end the game.

He scores as positive points all the remaining cards in players hand. Other players scores as negatives points all their cards in hand. All players scores as positive points the number of different colors of the Figure of Galipote, for each symbol.

boardgame.name: SolForge
boardgame.description:
(The game has been released and is available for free to download online.)

The creators of Ascension and Magic: The Gathering have joined forces to create a revolutionary digital trading card game -- SolForge combines the strategy and depth of a traditional trading card game experience with the convenience of online and mobile gaming. Players will be able to experience Solforge absolutely free and can grow their collection just by playing the game.

You construct your play deck before hand, but your hand cycles through, more similar to a deck building game. SolForge is differentiated in that every time you play a creature, its leveled up version also goes into your discard pile. Since you typically play two out of five cards per turn, this adds some subtlety to what you play.

SolForge currently supports building your own decks to play against your friends, compete in online tournaments, and automatching with players. Future development will allow you to explore a rich fantasy world in a single-player campaign mode in which your actions can affect the direction of the story.

SolForge is a free-to-play digital collectable strategy game that combines all the depth of a traditional trading card game experience with the convenience of online and mobile gaming. In SolForge, you take on the role of a Forgeborn, one of the select few who can wield the magic of the SolForge itself. You collect cards and use them to construct decks with ferocious creatures, imposing structures, and powerful spells to battle AI opponents in the single-player campaign mode or test your skills against other players in the arena.

The goal of a game of SolForge is to reduce your opponent’s health from one hundred to zero. How you do this - whether by attacking quickly with a swarm of creatures or playing defense until you have a single unstoppable monster - is really up to you.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Clacks: A Discworld Board Game
Clacks: A Discworld Board Game – Collector's Edition
Semafory: Hra ze Zeměplochy
Semafory: Rexhry
Świat Dysku: Sekary
boardgame.description:
Clacks: A Discworld Board Game is based on the "Clacks" semaphore messaging system — the fastest (non-magical) messaging system on the Discworld — featured in Sir Terry Pratchett's novel Going Postal.

Using a semaphore system of shuttered lamps on top of high towers, the Grand Trunk Semaphore Company has revolutionized long-distance communications on the Discworld. Their network of towers covers most of the Unnamed Continent, but now the old postal service is fighting back. Driven by the determination of newly "volunteered" Post Master Moist Von Lipwig, the Ankh-Morpork Post Office has challenged the Clacks operators to a race from Ankh-Morpork to Genua.

Play against your friends and claim the title of Fastest Clacks Operator on the line, or play together as a team to win the race across the Discworld and prove that Clacks is here to stay. In more detail, Clacks: A Discworld Board Game contains rules for a player vs. player game, a co-operative race game against the Post Office, and a children's introductory game.

boardgame.name: Brain Assist
boardgame.description:
Brain Assist or Touch de Uno DS is a puzzle video game released for Nintendo DS in Japan, North America, and the PAL region. Studies in the 1960s demonstrated the lateralization of brain function. The left-brain hemisphere deals with sequential analysis - reasoning using language, mathematics, abstraction and reasoning. Memory is primarily stored in a language format. The right hemisphere deals with auditory, visual, and spatial concepts (art, for example) dancing and gymnastics. There is an overlap, though. Brain Assist for the Nintendo DS aims to stimulate your right brain.

Source: Wikipedia, "Brain Assist", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: The Red Menace
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In 2012, Polish RPG publisher Gramel released their licensed version of Adamant Entertainment's Savage Worlds core book, THRILLING TALES 2nd Edition. Within it's pages was an additional chapter, exclusive to the Polish edition, detailing the use of the Soviets as villains for pulp adventures.

Now, for the first time in English, this additional material is being made available as bonus content for THRILLING TALES campaigns!

Pulp Villains: The Red Menace details the history of the Soviet Union from the Revolution until the pulp era of the 1930s, and features a collection of Soviet NPC archetypes from the Red Army to Dastardly Spies. Russian weapons of the 1930s are also detailed, as well as a section of suggestions for pulp plots featuring the Red Menace!

boardgame.name: Raiden
boardgame.description:
In the year 2090, Earth has suddenly become the target of deranged aliens known as the Cranassians. Following the invasion, the World Alliance Military builds a new cutting-edge weapon, the Raiden Supersonic Attack Fighter. Based on a captured alien craft, it is humanity's only hope for survival.

Raiden is a scrolling shooter arcade game that was developed by Seibu Kaihatsu. The title is in Japanese and means "Thunder And Lightning". In September 1990, Raiden hit the top of the arcade game popularity charts. The game was on the charts for over 38 months, including 26 months in the top ten. Due to the success of Raiden, several sequels and related games were made.

Raiden consists of eight vertical scrolling missions where the player maneuvers the Raiden craft dodging and destroying enemy robots, buildings, ground targets, and aircraft. There are bombs and missile powerups as well as collectable medals which add to the score. When the player dies, the fighter's fragments become projectiles that damage enemies.

After defeating the Stage 8 boss, the mission is completed and the player receives 1 million points. Following Stage 8 the game reverts to Stage 1. However, this time around the enemy shots travel faster and are fired at a more rapid rate.

Raiden was ported to the FM Towns Marty, PC Engine, Atari Jaguar, Atari Lynx, Amiga (unreleased prototype) and MS-DOS.

Source: Wikipedia, "Raiden (arcade game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Ruta
boardgame.description:
A Decktet game for two players, in which you are a merchant attempting to claim as many trade routes throughout the kingdom as you can.

Ruta is a game of card drafting and network building, inspired by the popular game Ticket to Ride. A 5x3 grid of cards is used to represent the people and places with which players are trying to establish trade routes. Players take turns drawing cards and playing those cards to claim routes (orthogonal connections between adjacent cards on the map). Tokens are used to mark each player's routes.

Points are awarded for each route that is claimed, and players earn bonus points for their longest continuous route. When one player is out of tokens, the game ends, and the player with the most points wins.

This game requires a Decktet extended deck and 20 tokens in 2 colors (10 of each color). Suit chips may be used.

boardgame.name: Bloodlines
boardgame.description:
It’s an age of kings and kingdoms, heirs and assassinations. You and your opponents are vying for control over the four royal bloodlines. To emerge the victor, you must carefully manage a mismatched court of nobles to create the most prestigious kingdom the world has ever seen.

Bloodlines is a micro game using 20 playing cards and 5 cubes. Each player drafts a hand of cards, each of which has a special ability and a point value that contributes to your influence in that suit's bloodline. Once all cards have been played, the prestige of any lines you control is based on presence of cards of that type in your opponent’s kingdoms.

Each card you play has an associated special ability, and that card remains in your Kingdom as influence in that bloodline. The card abilities are:


Ace (1 Influence): The Assassin may eliminate any unprotected card from the game, including any heirs placed on the card.
10 (2 Influence): The Castle protects all of the played cards in your kingdom from the effects of the Assassin and the Jack.
Jack (3 Influence): The Jack may swap any two unprotected played cards of equal Influence value. You may swap for a lower valued card if swapping from your own kingdom.
Queen (4 Influence): The Queen may produce an heir on any card you have played, including herself and cards in Castles. The heir increases this cards influence in that bloodline by 1.
King (5 Influence): The King has no ability, but he may be played directly into an empty Castle already in your Kingdom.


Full Rules available in the files section below

boardgame.name: Logic Levels
boardgame.description:
Back of Box

It's an amazing maze with prizes everywhere. Plan your best path, and start the ball rolling!

If you like mazes, you'll love LOGIC LEVELS.

First you tell the Magic Hand where to put the walls, bridges and springs to guide the ball through the maze. The more prizes it hits the more points you will score.

But that's just the beginning. Once the ball starts rolling, you can change the maze as you go. Move the bridges back and forth. Send the walls up and down. Aim for a spring and KABOING!--up you go to a higher floor. Land in a paint bucket and KERPLOP!--the ball changes to a new color. Then hit a prize of the same color and you score extra points.

In LOGIC LEVELS you have to think fast--and that's why the fun will last and last.

LOGIC LEVELS was designed by Frieda Lekkerkerker.

Learning Value: Thinking logically and planning ahead are important steps in learning. LOGIC LEVELS challenges children to predict the outcome of a complex sequence of actions. It also encourages quick decision-making. Ages 7-12

boardgame.name: Black Plague Blind Date
boardgame.description:
Dating is hard in the 14th century, and as a matchmaker, business is slim. The plague has most folks too afraid to leave their homes, let alone go out looking for romance. Literacy is very low, so the letters you receive from clients are oftten difficult to make out. To make matters worse, you're not the only match-maker in town.

To come out on top of your rival matchmakers you will have to go with what little information you can decipher and find matches for your clients. At times it will be in your best interest you to work with your opponents, at others it will benefit you to set devious traps for them.

Love is in the air! But so is the plague...

In Black Plague Blind Date, players take turns choosing a card from their hands to play face down as a "blind date". They then must truthfully describe their card with 1-3 colored "info cubes" (blue = male, pink = female, black = infected, white = healthy, green = high class, brown = low class). Cards change hands during the exchange phase, then each player plays a second card face up next to any blind date. Blind dates are revealed and reputation points are scored based upon the best/worst dates. Matching two healthy townsfolk or two plague-ridden citizens will earn you points, but don't accidentally cross the two and spread the plague! The game is played over 4 "seasons" (rounds) with each season affecting scoring in a significant way. It's a quick-playing game of deduction and bluffing for 3-4 players.

Full rules are available under the Files section of this entry.


Black Plague Blind Date won the February 2013 Boardroomers Game Design Contest in the 3+ Players category. Entrants in the contest were limited to using no more than 20 standard playing cards and 10 cubes.

boardgame.name: Elite: Station Run
boardgame.description:
From the Website:

"Station Run is a board game version of the computer game Elite, released by Ian Bell and David Braben in the mid 80s.

You and some other players need to get from one end of the game board to the other without your ship being destroyed. Other players might do it, or some of the random people who ply the spacelanes might get to you first.

Station Run is a free-to-download game. No need to whip out the credit card for this one, and no need to try and remember your paypal password."

From the free PDF rules:

"Station Run is a game for one to four players. Each player is the pilot of a ship which has just hyperspaced into the system. They must get to the nearby planet’s space station in order to sell cargo, refuel or whatever else they might want to do. The player can take on a number of roles. Traders are ferrying cargo between systems to make profit, which they can use to improve their ship or buy another one. Bounty Hunters are seeking out wrongdoers and bringing them to justice. Pirates are only interested in plundering the traders and stealing their cargo. Miners are looking for asteroids to mine for valuable minerals.

The aim of the game is to get from one end of the game board to the other in one piece. Random encounters may occur, as other spacefarers and asteroids make their way around the planet’s
orbitspace. The game is designed to be open-ended and as freeform as possible (just like the computer game)."

boardgame.name: High Heavens
boardgame.description:
High Heavens sets the players in the clouds, fighting for ultimate power above the earth.

High Heavens is a two player, tactical strategy game played on a hex grid, pitting Norse gods against Greek gods. The game is won when either all 12 gods in an entire pantheon is wiped out, or when Asgard or Mt. Olympus is destroyed. Players draw five cards every turn and then are allowed 3 actions. These actions can include Invoking a god, Moving, Attacking, playing a Divine Power card, using a god's Special Ability or Acquiring a dropped bonus chip. Red chips are stacked under each character to represent that characters health. Modifiers such as Attack Bonus, Armor, or Disabled are also represented by different colored chips. No two gods are alike, and their actions and abilities closely correlate to the mythology they were derived from. The luck of the cards you draw forces you to change your strategy from game to game. There is no reshuffling when you are out of cards, so once a god is dead, they're dead. Game play takes about a half an hour to an hour, depending on the players' skill, luck of the draw and the strategies used.

Created by award-winning video game industry veteran Ryan Lesser (Guitar Hero, Rock Band, Beatles:Rock Band, Dance Central...), High Heavens is a 2-player, expandable board game that utilizes lessons learned from 15 years of video game creation and a lifetime of playing board games.

boardgame.name: Wayne Gretzky's 3D Hockey '98
Wayne Gretzky's 3D Hockey 98
boardgame.description:
Wayne Gretzky's 3D Hockey '98 is an ice hockey game for the Nintendo 64 and PlayStation. The game is endorsed by hockey star, Wayne Gretzky and is the sequel to Wayne Gretzky's 3D Hockey. The game gained widespread criticism for several perceived shortcomings, including being unfit as a pure hockey simulator. This left many simulation enthusiasts disappointed, but many arcade fans delighted.

Gameplay consists of two basic options: Arcade and Simulation. Players have the ability to customize period length, camera angle, line changes, penalties and rink size. In addition, fatigue, fighting and puck-streak can be toggled on or off.

Simulation Mode

Simulation mode is designed to emulate the real game of hockey. Players may play five, four, or three to a side, depending on preference. Recognition of penalties, off-sides, and icing are all optional, but two-line pass is not considered. Period length can be selected between 5, 10, 15, and 20 minutes.

Arcade Mode

In Arcade mode checking, hooking, and tripping are more violent. Fights occur with greater frequency, and penalties are disregarded entirely. Additionally, players may utilize a "power shot" which lights the net on fire when a goal is scored. As a resule of these changes, the Arcade mode tends to be more exciting.

Source: Wikipedia, "Wayne Gretzky's 3D Hockey '98", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.description:
publisher blurb

ISCHADRA, GRANDMOTHER OF ASSASSINS - CR 14, Advanced Soulbound Doll Assassin 10/Inquisitor 2

A horrifying new Infamous Adversary for the Pathfinder RPG!
She wears the guise of a doll, a child-like construct of porcelain and wire, but cold sentience seemingly teems in her empty eye sockets. She stares with an eery mute silence, giving you a moment for your brain to adjust to what it is seeing. A doll given life, bestowed with an ancient weapon of vengeance and purpose. With an inhuman leap her blade buries deep in your throat. As the last of your lifeblood spills her words take form in your mind, and you know why the Grandmother of Assassins has come.
Infamous Adversaries contains: one ready to use villain, complete with equipment, a rich background including motives, history, personality, network, resources, lair, tactics, morale, advancement options, a quote, plot hooks to easily insert them into your campaign, local lore, full color art and a vibrant description. The Infamous Adversaries characters are designed to challenge an entire party; not just in combat, but also through less direct methods requiring careful planning and confrontation.
Contained within is 26 pages of original TPK content including a full depiction of our Infamous Adversary, plus original short fiction, a new deity (Naelib, Lord of Murder), and faction (The Ebon Hand), several supporting cast characters (ever wonder what a Grandfather of Assassins was like?) and monsters (the all new Spectral Host), plus our personally designed Hero Lab files for use in customizing our characters and content in your campaigns!
Give your players a reason to hate again. You can blame it on us...

boardgame.name: Skeletons
boardgame.description:
publisher blurb

Give Skeletons New Life!
Skeletons have always been a danger to young heroes venturing into lonely graveyards and ominous tombs, but these classic monsters are quickly replaced by their more powerful undead. Monster Focus: Skeletons is here to give Game Masters a wealth of options to give these clattering undead new "life".
Inside, you'll find a number of options for player characters facing off against skeletons. Options like the Bone Breaker feat, which allows a character to bypass damage reduction, or the new spell Maul of the Righteous, which can crush most skeletons with a single swing. In addition, there are a wide variety of new rules for Game Master to use in their game. There are 7 new magic items like the bone sword, a dreadful weapon that can turn any creature it kills into a skeleton under the wielders control. Game Masters will also find 3 new types of skeleton inside, including the skeletal lord that command the dead and create new minions to serve him.
Monster Focus is a series of short, easy to integrate PDFs, designed to make one classic monster the central theme for an adventure or even a small campaign. Each PDF in the series includes options for player characters and game masters, including new feats, spells, magic items, and more! Written by veteran game designer, Jason Bulmahn, you can be sure that these rules will fit seamlessly into your campaign.

boardgame.name: Devilmount
boardgame.description:
From the publisher:

What is DEVILMOUNT? DEVILMOUNT is a fully-playable parody of the OSR's infamous "lost dungeon." The draft manuscript has been heavily re-flavored, revised, and edited into a new experience. Instead of being reverential toward the idea of a Gygaxian megadungeon, DEVILMOUNT reads like a dungeon created by a sixteen year-old who is into Satan, ufo conspiracy theories, and drinking cough syrup.

User note:

The "'lost dungeon'" in the description is Dwimmermount. Devilmount is a parody of a dungeon that, as of Devilmount's March 2013 publication, has only been published in draft form. It was deliberately published with only the artists credited.

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of great features to add to the portcullises in your dungeon. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Portcullises is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

Dungeon Dressing: Portcullises presents:


One table providing detailed descriptions of a portcullises’ characteristics.
One table presenting additional portcullis features such as contents, hidden treasures, magical properties and more!
Several clever portcullis-based traps (CRs 6-8).

boardgame.name: Solar
boardgame.description: Solar will attempt to usher in a new style of card games with its almost unheard of game mechanics. The game will start with both players choosing who picks the first character, that person starts on defense, the other play, on offense. Then, they both take turns choosing characters until they both have 12 card decks to play with. Each character shall feature its own art work and class, as well as one, two, or three attacks to use while on offense,and one or two defense moves while on defense. At the beginning of each turn, both players draw 3 characters from the top of the deck, and put one on the battlefield, and the other two on the bottom of his/her deck. Then, the player on offense may use his characters attack skills on his/her opponent's characters. If the hit lands successfully, the character is defeated. The game is over,and the winner decided, when one player has lost all of his characters and is labeled the loser.

boardgame.name: Carnival Zombie
boardgame.description:
The ancient manuscripts talk about a Leviathan, a huge creature lying on the silt bed of the lagoon on whose back the city has its foundations. All manuscripts agree on its eternal sleep and they all tell that the beast will wake up one day, shaking the city from its muddy roots, smashing the vitrified stilts on which the city stands, and crashing it into the seething sea where the monster will rise. The ancients say, however, that there will be signs; it is written that the Venetians will feel the tremors, that they would therefore save themselves from the monster, who will recover his freedom by plunging into the waves a deserted city.

But there were no signs. What ancients did not know is that the Leviathan is not alive. For centuries, the city lived and prospered on the back of a corpse. That corpse, though, is now awakening – and with it the dead arise from the lagoon...

In the cooperative game Carnival Zombie, players lead a group of characters who are fleeing on terra firma from the terror that has emerged from the lagoon of Venice. This group of characters must make its way through hordes of rotting "Infected" to leave the city, and players need to rush as the Leviathan upon which the foundations of Venice were built is awakening. Thus, it's only a matter of time before the city sinks in the dark waters of the lagoon.

Each game is divided into several nights and days. During the nights, players hide in trenches behind the barricades to resist the attacks of the Infected. During the day, players move through the city, which is shaken by tremors. The Infected are drawn by the groans of the Leviathan in the abyss to help their master free itself from the rotting stilts that nail it to the silt bed.

Players have several ways to get out of town, but little time to do it – and their path is hindered by the bosses, the most implacable servants of the Leviathan. If the players do make it out, they can assess their skills – and set a goal for next time – by counting the points scored during the game.

boardgame.name: Beneath the Windowless Tower
boardgame.description:
From the first page:

Malazar the Mage, like all great wizards, was a noted eccentric. His particular obsession was the collection of certain rare and bizarre antiquities, unearthed at great time and personal expense from long-forgotten buried cities where saner men feared to tread.
It was on his final such expedition that Malazar reputedly uncovered a jewel of great value and magical power, the so-called Egg of Desire. In an area of remote hills, he constructed a high tower in which to house his prize – a tower with neither windows nor doors.
As the years drew on, Malazar began to disdain city life. He withdrew more and more to his strange, windowless tower, conducting his business by emissary. It is now more than a decade since there has been any word from either Malazar or his agents, and persistent rumour among the more knowledgeable circles of thieves and treasure- hunters has it that the mage is dead, and within the tower his jewel lies free for the taking - if only there were some way to get inside...

boardgame.name: The Garden of al-Astorion (OGL 3.5)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Gentle Reader!
The Garden of al-Astorion is the translation of an adventure module I originally designed in a single evening for a Hungarian game convention and later revised and expanded for self publication on a whim. To this date, it remains the only adventure to be released in the country under the d20 license – although it was successful as an amateur effort, others were reluctant to follow in its steps, and I lacked the time to do a follow-up.
Although more than three years have passed since initial inception and almost three since first publication, I nevertheless decided to do a translation for the benefit of interested gamers who didn’t have a chance to read the original. Although I would do some things differently if I designed the module today (hopefully better, too), I decided to preserve the original as well as a translation could allow instead. I believe it can and it should stand on its own merits. Let it be judged with this consideration – but let it be Judged with a critical eye towards its failings!

boardgame.name: Temple of the Hag
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Finding the Temple of the Hag is not as simple as getting from point A to point B. The dark spirits that live within keep their temples well hidden. Sword-bladed grass, quicksand, and the dreaded doomsday skeeters are only a few of the dangers that skulk along the haunted paths of the Swamp of Doom. Somewhere within, living in the shadow of the Bat-Winged Fiend himself, the mysterious swamp hag bottles her stolen souls.

This scenario is set in Scott Malthouse’s Peakvale campaign setting. While it can be incorporated into any other T&T world, such as Trollworld or Elder, we recommend that you check out Trollish Delver Games for details first. The player characters should either have Combat Adds of 50 or more or be able to cast at least a couple of 3rd level spells. It is assumed that the players have survived the [No Fences to Mend] scenario (and possibly had a few [Hot Nights in Lowhollow]), but the scenario can just as easily be played as a standalone adventure.

It should be noted that while this scenario is designed for T&T 7 and 7.5, it can easily be adjusted to any edition.

boardgame.name: Jekyll & Hyde
boardgame.description:
A two-player, print and play game designed for 2013 Two-Player Print-and-Play Design Contest.

Players take turns moving a pawn around London using tokens as action points. The Jekyll player is trying to discover the parts of a cure, to rid themselves of the Hyde personality. Hyde is trying to take full control of the pawn, by limiting the Jekyll players ability to use the tokens.

Most of the players' actions turn into a tug of war with the other player. Moving the pawn can place it in an advantageous location for the other player, and playing cards gives the other player a chance to draw them into their hand. Players must try to accomplish their goals without aiding their opponent.

boardgame.description:
Table of Contents:

EDITORIAL

SALISBURY PLAIN (Hot War)
To the west of the capital, beyond the ruins of Porton Down, lies the blasted wilderness of Salisbury Plain, once the site of the Army’s most ambitious training exercises, and now home to the monstrous survivors of the War.

SHADOW MASTERY (Solipsist)
An in-depth look at how to create, prepare and use the Shadow in play, with optional rules to allow players to better investigate, destroy and embrace its manifestations.

DIRK HEMLOCK AND THE BLACKFEL INCIDENT (Pulp!)

A quickstart scenario for Pulp! – a miniatures game of two-fisted action!

QUARRY HILL BUNKER/GARTWOOD ROYAL HOSPITAL (Dead of Night)

Two terrifying locations for games of Dead of Night! Clamber down into the dank, dangerous depths of Quarry Hill Bunker, or pry up a board, clamber in and walk the wards of the abandoned Gartwood Royal Hospital. But always remember to bring a torch...

TOY SOLDIERS (Contenders)
Boxers aren’t the only people who struggle with adversity and fight for money. This light-hearted article explains how to use Contenders to tell stories about Wargamers and the unique challenges they face.

FIRMS & HATCHETMEN (Hot War)
A look at using some real-life criminals in games of Hot War. In the aftermath of an apocalyptic war, those who prey on the weak and vulnerable will survive and thrive.

DISPOSABLE HEROES (3:16 Carnage Amongst The Stars)
This supplement for 3:16 Carnage Amongst The Stars has exclusive material, including additional planet descriptors and a list of sub-missions for the disposable heroes of the 3:16th Expeditionary Force.

PRETENDERS (Contenders)
A companion to the more light hearted Toy Soldiers, Pretenders is a wargame modification to the Contenders engine. Pretenders provides a campaign narrative and roleplaying slant for any wargaming system.

I DEMAND SATISFACTION (Duty and Honour)
Two men meeting on a misty moor, pistols drawn and ready - there is only one way to settle a matter of honour between gentlemen, a duel! ‘I Demand Satisfaction’ brings tense and deadly duelling to Duty & Honour, including rules, new traits and a despicable NPC.

BROTHERS IN ARMS (Mob Justice)
Life as one of the O’Leary brothers has never been easy. Your father runs the Irish gangs and your siblings are in deep with the ‘less polite’ elements of Chicago society. Now your Father lies dead, shot by one the factions after his turf, and it is up to you and your brothers to sort it out.

boardgame.name: Cards Against Humanity: Third Expansion
boardgame.description:
The third expansion to Cards Against Humanity features 100 new cards – 25 black question/statement cards and 75 white answer cards – to be used with the base game, in addition to 12 blank cards.

In this card game, players take turns being the Card Czar, which means they read a black question card or a fill-in-the-blank statement card. The other players then select a white answer card from the ten in hand that they think best or most humorously fits the question/statement. The Card Czar then shuffles the answers and chooses the one he likes best, with that answer's owner receiving the black card as his "awesome point" for winning the round.

Once a player has at least one awesome point, he can wager an awesome point when giving a white answer card in order to throw in a second answer card, theoretically giving him a better chance to be chosen. The winner of the round receives the original black card as well as any that are wagered in that round.

Play continues until a pre-determined score is reached, or until everyone is tired from laughing so hard.

boardgame.name: Obelisk of Forgotten Memories
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The Obelisk is moderately large outdoor adventure with a small attached dungeon for a party levels 1-3.

This adventure was occasioned by my players deciding to take a lark into the wilderness rather than exploring Patrick Wetmore wonderful megadungeon the Anomalous Subsurface Environment (ASE). It's my own attempt to create another, smaller adventure location that seems reasonable within Pat's world. It contains several elements (guns, ancient technology, God's eye's) that won't make sense outside of ASE, but I suppose it could be run as a simple graveyard based cult-smashing expedition in with a little modification. It's also an attempt at an adventure in the old style of the TSR products I grew up with, or at least as I remember them played in the hands of murderously inclined pre-teen boys on lazy Summer afternoons. The encounters within are not scaled to allow a 1st level party to win in a stand-up heroic fight. There are encounters, and even individual creatures (especially the special random encounters), quite capable of slaughtering a party within a couple rounds, but this is how it should be, as they can be avoided or negotiated with.

boardgame.name: The Terminal Hours
boardgame.description:
Author's description

The Terminal Hours is a narrative RPG where the GM takes the role of Coyote, a (mostly) benevolent trickster spirit, and the players take the role of a person during the last hours of their life. These people have to fight their way past the challenges of the spirit world and the real world in order to accomplish their dying wishes, but they have to work together to have any chance of survival. This is a mostly traditional RPG, where the players act and the GM narrates.

The principals of the game are collaborative storytelling, emergent character stories, and that you play to find out what happens - whether the characters “succeed” or “fail” should be totally subordinate to the story at hand.

boardgame.name: Speed
boardgame.description:
The object of Speed is for the player to move his/her ship, plane, car and train along the designated routes from start to finish. The first player completing the routes for all four vehicles wins. Two to four players may play. There are 16 player pieces. One each of ship, plane, car and train in four colors (red, green, black and blue)

Movement is driven by card play. Each player selects four cards from the 40 card deck to start the game. Each player must maintain four cards in hand at all times. There are four "suites" (in red and black) corresponding to each of the four types of vehicles. The first player plays a card in the suite of his/her choice, announces the card and plays it face up. The player then draws from the deck to replenish the hand. The other players follow, and the player who played the highest value card in the suite lead gets to move the associated piece that number of spaces forward along the corresponding route. If a player does not have a card of the suite lead, they must play another card from another suite. The used cards are placed in a discard pile and shuffled if the draw pile is depleted.

boardgame.name: Assassin's Creed: Arena
boardgame.description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Assassin's Creed: Arena – based on the Assassin's Creed video game series from Ubisoft – players compete to uncover the best targets for assassination, but before you can go in for the kill, sometimes you have to deal with pesky guards as well as your opponents. Players will collect cards and treasure, move guards, and hide within the city of Constantinople until they find their time to strike. Combat is handled through cardplay, and the player who best manages his cards will have the best chance at victory.

At the start of each player's turn, he draws an Event card, which can spawn new targets in the outer city, move guards, or allow you to find a tunnel to another section of the city. Moving guards is a great way to get them away from you and place them near your opponents. Targets cannot be assassinated while a guard is nearby, but fortunately the guards can be dispatched if need be.

Cards in hand drive the action, but they are also your hit points. If you run out of cards in hand, you die — but just like in a video game, you will soon respawn at your starting area. Moving and attacking targets (or your fellow players) requires playing cards, so doing too much all at once can be risky. Couple that with trying to avoid the guards and you are in for a tension-filled game of cat-and-mouse. To replenish your hand, complete objectives on your movement cards or hide. Hiding in the outer city is easy and grants you lots of extra cards. When you enter the merchant district or the area around the palace, there just aren’t as many places to hide and you will not draw many cards.

Combat is handled through cardplay. No dice are required, although a six-sided die is included to resolve some guard movement. Do you save your best cards for movement or to go in for the kill? He who risks the most has the chance for the most reward!

boardgame.name: Global Operations
boardgame.description:
Global Operations is a first-person tactical shooter computer game developed by Barking Dog Studios and published by both Crave Entertainment and Electronic Arts. It was released in March 2002, following its public multiplayer beta version which contained only the Quebec map. The full game featured thirteen maps and featured both a single player and a multiplayer mode, which supported up to twenty-four players and three teams. Afterwards, a multiplayer demo with only the Antarctica map was released.
The game itself was focused on firearms in a special forces setting, with a mixture of military and counterterrorist type themes. The game featured a large number of firearms, numbering in the dozens and including a wide selection of handguns and rifles. Many of them could be further customized as well. For example, a C-mag and silencer could be added. The multi-player offered different classes (Reconnaissance, Commando, Medic, Heavy Weapons, Sniper, Demolitions and Intelligence Officer) with extra abilities and class-specific weapons. All classes could use all other classes' firearms (by picking them up off the battlefield), but each class might not have the same level of skill with a given weapon (such as less precision).
Other features existed as well, including a life-sign tracking device, as well other game items like tear gas grenades, smoke grenades and medkit. A LAW (Lightweight Anti-tank Weapon) could be used, as well as night vision and thermal vision.

Source: Wikipedia, "Global Operations", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Rainbow Park
boardgame.description:
The rain has stopped and the sun is out with a shining smile, but the beautiful rainbow is nowhere to be seen! It's all because those playful colors of the rainbow got distracted by the fun facilities in the park. They are running around and having a good time all over the park. Let's go find those colors and make the rainbow appear!

Contents: 54 game cards, including 49 Element cards and 5 pass cards.

This is a memory game where all of the cards are double-sided. Players take turns turning over cards to score matches. Players can collect pass cards and re-arrange the position of the game cards surrounding that card.

The game ends when the number of Element cards left on the playing surface is less than or equal to the number of the colors used to play the game. For example, if 5 colors were used to play the game, the game ends when there are 5 or fewer Element cards left on the playing surface.

At the end of the game, each player should add up the values of the cards he/she has collected: 1 point for each Element card, and 2 points for each Pass card. The highest scoring player wins the game.

boardgame.name: Pog Word Builder Game
boardgame.description:
Pogs are small cardboard disks with a variety of designs on them; they were popular in the early 90's. In the original game of Pogs, players would gamble Pogs from their own collection in an attempt to expand their collection further. Players would stack Pogs face down in a stack and throw a 'Kini' (a hard plastic disk, sometimes referred to as a 'Slammer') from above in an attempt to turn the Pogs over and claim them for their collection.

Pog word builder combines the classic action of Pog with the challenging gameplay of Scrabble. Use 1 letter and 2 letter Pogs to build the biggest words possible. Pog's are obtained in the same way as the original game, by by trying to turn over a stack of Pogs containing unknown letters. The player who builds the most words wins.

As the emphasis of Pog word builder is on the number of words, rather than the length or the quality of words, the game is easily accessible to young players.
